p: In several studies, SARS-CoV‑2 RNA has been demonstrated by reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) analysis (see below) in stool and sewage, and occasionally infectious virus has been recovered from faecal samples [ 24, 25]. Moreover, SARS-CoV‑2 has been shown to replicate in enterocytes of human small intestinal organoids [ 26], and the viral N has been detected by immunofluorescence microscopy in the cytoplasm of gastric, duodenal and rectal epithelial cells but not in oesophageal epithelial cells of endoscopic biopsies [ 27]. This raises the possibility of faecal transmission of SARS-CoV‑2, although formal evidence for this has not yet been obtained.
